learning_outcomes.description: Transfer a biological hypothesis into a mathematical representation
Understand how models can be used to gain understanding of complex systems and to make predictions
Understand the advantages and disadvantages of different types of models
Create simple models of biological processes
Write simple programs using MATLAB to solve mathematical problems that arise in models

assessments.weighting: <dd>48% Each assigment bears 8% weight in the aggregated mark. </dd>
assessments.task_description: You will be asked to use and/or write programs related to the lecture material.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your assignment electronically on Blackboard
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: You will be asked to use and/or write computer programs related to the lecture material.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The examination will be invigilated and on campus. Further details will be provided to students before the examination period.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

There are 2 hours of lectures per week. You need to attend ALL lectures. Lectures define the course material. They set out the basic theory and demonstrate techniques for modelling and problem solving. They cover all the core material required for the course and are also used to provide administrative information for the course. Students are expected to take notes during each lecture as the lecturer works through the material and examples, and answer or ask questions when opportunities arise


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Computer Labs

Tutorial problems, writing programs in Julia (or Matlab) to support the material presented in lectures, and presenting simulation results in a short report.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05, L06
